conclusion: To determine the change in magnetic flux passing through the coil when it rotates 60° downward around the z-axis, we can use the formula for magnetic flux: Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ).
B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the coil, θ is the angle between the magnetic field vector and the normal to the plane of the coil.
Initially, the coil is in the position shown in Picture 1.

premise: The angle between the magnetic field (along the positive x-axis) and the normal to the plane of the coil is 90° - 60° = 30°.
conclusion: The cosine of this angle is cos(30°) = √3/2.
The initial magnetic flux is Φ_initial = 0.01√3 Wb.

premise: After rotating the coil 60° downward, the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the plane of the coil becomes 90° - 60° = 30° again.
conclusion: The cosine of this angle remains the same as before: cos(30°) = √3/2.
The final magnetic flux is Φ_final = 0.01√3 Wb.
The change in magnetic flux is ΔΦ = 0.
